name: Isoetes anamariae
distribution: Bahia (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);Pernambuco (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.1640/0002-8444-112.3.190 Etymology: the specific epithet honours Ana Maria Giulietti-Harley, the Brazilian botanist who has been extensively studying the Brazilian semiarid flora and first located this species in its type locality in 1992.

name: Isoetes cipoensis
collectorTeam: J.B.S Pereira, P.H. Labiak, & M. Reginato
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Jaboticatubas, Parque Nacional da Serra do Cipo, 700-720 m
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364422X16512564801704 Etymology: named after the Parque Nacional da Serra do Cipo, which is the Brazilian permanent conservation area where it was collected.

name: Isoetes harleyi
locality: Xique-Xique, Serra do Açuruá, temporary ponds on the left side (western direction) of the road BR-330 (from Xique-Xique to Gentio do Ouro), c. 399 m
remarks: doi:10.1640/0002-8444-112.3.190 Etymology: the specific epithet is named in honour of the British botanist Raymond M.Harley who first collected this species in 1977.

name: Isoetes longifolia
locality: Formosa do Rio Preto, Povoado de Sao Marcelo, Rio Preto, 495 m
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364422X16512564801704 Etymology: name refers to its long leaves that are fully submerged deep in the water
